div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The Washington Post, November 10, 1900
div1.p:
It gratified us to read in the New York
Sun of the 8th instant a letter to the
editor from Maj. Gen. Leonard Wood,
military governor of Cuba. We had
known that there was a rumor current in-
dicating something in the nature of a
friction between Gen. Wood and Gen.
Ludlow. Gossip, more or less irresponsi-
ble, had it that the former had, by impli-
cation, accused the latter of having sup-
pressed the yellow fever reports in Ha-
vana a year ago.

The prevalent idea last January was
that there had been little or no yellow
fever in Havana during 1899, and public
opinion, with characteristic innocence,
jumped to the conclusion that this im-
agined immunity was the result--the log-
ical and inevitable result--of the street
sweeping and other sanitary measures
employed by the Brooke regime, under
the immediate direction and control of
Gen. Ludlow. After Gen. Wood's acces-
sion to the governorship announcements
of yellow fever came to be of almost daily
occurrence, and as the summer deepened
and the disease extended its field, there
ensued a popular conviction that Gen.
Wood must have set aside the sanitary
plans and dismissed the sanitary precau-
tions which, under Gen. Ludlow's admin-
istration, had (sic) eradicated the pest
and destroyed the material upon which
it depended for vitality.

It is not difficult to believe that, in
these circumstances, Gen. Wood resented
such ignorant and unwarranted assump-
tions. Nor need we cherish any surprise
on account of his attempt to exonerate
himself from charges and suspicions so
undeserved. He was, in fact, held re-
sponsible for all the yellow fever in and
about Havana during 1900, and, to make
the matter worse, was twitted with the
suggestion that if he had not neglected
the example and advice of Gen. Ludlow
the immunity existing when he took
charge would have been perpetuated. One
can readily forgive him, therefore, for
having resented this absurd injustice and
for having shown--as seems to be the
fact--that there was no immunity; that
yellow fever had not been eradicated, and
that whatever merit resided in the sani-
tary system inaugurated by Gen. Ludlow
had been carefully cultivated under his regime.

It is a mistake to suppose, however,
that Gen. Wood, in defending himself
against misrepresentation, intended to
cast, or, indeed, did cast, the smallest
reflection upon Gens. Brooke and Ludlow.
He did not assert, or even suggest, as has
been alleged in certain quarters, that
those officers withheld the facts concern-
ing yellow fever while they were in
charge of the situation. We give what
he says on this point in his letter:

“I did not state, directly or indirectly, that the
fever situation was concealed. I stated the fever
situation last December, saying that in December,
1899, there were more deaths in the civil popula-
tion from yellow fever than in any December in
ten years, and that the fever was with us through-
out the winter. I stated also that at present the
exact fever situation was given to the press for
general publication daily, and that in the fall of
1898 (1899) this method of publication was not
adopted. Statements then, I believe, were made
monthly, and comparatively little was heard of
yellow fever.

“The purpose of my statement was to correct an
impression which I found to be generally prevalent,
namely, that the yellow fever situation in Havana
must be due to lack of proper sanitary precautions,
and that it was in remarkable contrast with the
conditions of last year, and in correcting this I
stated that the conditions of this year were due
to the enormous number of Spanish immigrants
pouring into Cuba through this port, all of them
food for fever.

“I also stated that Havana was cleaner to-day
than ever, inasmuch as the sanitary work inaugu-
rated by Gen. Ludlow is being pushed forward
with the same degree of intelligence and energy,
and under the same personnel, as during his gov-
ernorship of the city; that the sanitary condition
of the city was better than before, as shown by
the total death rate from all causes, even including
yellow fever.

“There was nothing in my statements which
could, directly or indirectly, be taken as a charge
that there was any concealment of yellow fever
last year. Such an inference is unfair to me and
unjust to the officers in charge at Havana. The
misstatements in this particular should be cor-
rected.”

It appears, therefore, all these false im-
pressions have arisen out of a misunder-
standing. Last year the yellow fever re-
ports were promulgated only at long in-
tervals, thus attracting little attention.
Under Gen. Wood's management of af-
fairs they are given out daily, thus keep-
ing the facts constantly in view. The
difference is one of systems. Gen. Wood
has not cast the smallest reflection upon
Gen. Ludlow. On the contrary, he has
paid him the sincere compliment of per-
petuating with sleepless energy his sani-
tary plans and methods. Gen. Wood sim-
ply objects to unwarranted and injurious
criticism, and in that he deserves and
will receive the sympathy of all just men.

We gather from this utterance that
Gen. Wood does not accept street sweep-
ing and carbolic acid as yellow fever de-
stroyers. That, however, was to have
been expected in his case.
